evidence: An equiatomic, single-phase TiZrNbHfTa high-entropy alloy was subjected to high-pressure torsion, leading to a grain size below 100 nm. Isochronal heat treatments (1 h) resulted in a hardness increase from 420 HV1 for the as-processed state to 530 HV1 for an annealing temperature of 500 C

The evolution of the microstructure and hardness as a function of the shear strain g during HPT processing is presented in Fig.  1bee ). Hardness values were obtained by averaging four indents at an equivalent radial position, the standard deviation is indicated by the error bars (Fig.  1b ). The coarse-grained, as-received material has a hardness of 309 ± 6 HV1. The hardness increases with increasing strain up to about 419.4 ± 2.5 HV1 for g ~40, for higher shear strains a plateau is reached.

Grain refinement via HPT processing leads to a significant increase in the materials strength, the tensile strength of the HPT samples is around 1900 MPa. More surprisingly, despite the large increase in strength, the specimens remain fairly ductile with a total elongation to failure of 7.9%.
After the maximum hardness of approximately 530 HV1 is reached for 1 h of annealing at 500 C, the material starts to get softer again with prolonged heat treatment time.

HPT-processing of the coarse-grained TiZrNbHfTa alloy results in a significant grain refinement down to a minimum grain size of approximately 50 nm and, without losing the single-phase character, leads to a more than twofold increase in tensile strength up to 1900 MPa.
